Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

for Port Sudan and Soakin direct returning from Soakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6pm A steamer leave Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Soakin, Mesowah, Hodeidab, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.

div.head: PRESS IN WAR TIME
div.p: The question of the Press in time of war has now passed into its penultimate stage.The Prime Minister has taken it under his official wing and, lhas placed it upon the list of Government measures with which he hopes to deal next year. That is a decision (says the "Morning Post") upon which both the Press and the Government are to be congratulated the Press for voluntarily raising the question and in a sense asking to be restrained generally where restraint is essential to the national interest and the Government for taking the matter up in a straightforward and effective fashion. Mr. Arthur Lee, who as an ex Army officer, our Military Attache at Washington during the Spanish American War, and a Civil Lord of the Admiralty under the late Government, probably knows the ins and outs of the subject as well as any man in the House recently asked the Prime Minister whether his attention had been called to the recent conference of newspaper proprietors and editors, "at which there was a unanimous expression of opinion in favor of restricting or controlling the dissemination of news in time of war," and what action he proposed to take in consequence. The Prime Minister answered that the matter was being considered by the Committee of Imperial Defence and that he hoped to bring in a Bill dealing with it early next year. Mr. Lee very properly asked whether the Bill might not be introduced this session so that the Press might have an opportunity of studying its provisions at leisure. Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman replied that there were means of communicating with the Press other than by introducing a Bill in the House. We take this to me that nothing in the way of hasty legislation is contemplated sad that the Press will either be consulted during the period of drafting the Bill or that the Bill when completed will be referred to the Press for criticism and suggestions. In either case the Government is plainly prepared to collaborate with the Press in the work of formulating a measures that will secure the maximum of safety to the State with the minimum of interference with legitimate journalistic activities. It was for this purpose that the Conference of June 21 authorised the Sub-Committee of the Newspaper Society to add to its numbers men with special knowledge of the points at issue and to consider any Bill that might be drafted. The Government need not hesitate to treat the enlarged Sub-Committee as fully representative of the Press as a whole. We would suggest that the right course to take is for the Government to draft the sort of Bill it would like to passed, and for the Sub Committee of the Newspaper society to bring its provisions as far as possible into harmony with the opinions expressed at the recent conference, and, if necessary to call a further conference. The resultant would probably be a measure prohibiting in time of war and when war is imminent the unauthorized publications as news of naval and military movements. If there were incorporated in such a measure the guarantee which the Committee of Imperial Defence but already informally offered-guarantee, for instances that it would only be invoked in the event of an imminent war with a first class Power, that it would come to operate automatically on the conclusion of peace, and that its administration would be in civil hands-the Press would, we believe, be found ready to accept it. In the long run the three interests of journalism and the true interests of the nation must be identical. The Press cannot gain where the nation loses, and that the nation s tands to lose heavily by the unrestricted publication of news in time of war is very evident. Journalists desire to relieve their profession from its liability to become at any moment a source of peril to the country.

div.head: A Nile Tragedy
div.p: On Sunday last three Italians were making a boating excursion on the Nile, near Embaban Bridge when the boat collided with another and capsized. The three men fell into the water, and one of them was drowned being unable to swim. His companions escaped. The body of the drowned man was found the next day near Rod el-Farag.

div.head: A Brute in Human Form.
div.p: A terrible story is published by a Cairo contemporary which shows that Egypt can boast some imported savages in every way equal to the Manoufiah product. It is stated that a Greek servant girl who had been employed for several years at the house of one Ch. Callicopoulo, a Cairo bootmaker, was recently accused by her master of the theft of money and jewels. To extort a confession her scoundrelly employer beat the girl most cruelly, kicked her, poured boiling oil over her hands and wrists, and finally tied her up and tortured her by applying boiling eggs to the armpits! These last tortures inflicted such excruciating pain that the poor girl died of the shock. The Greek Consulate has ordered Dr. Lambros to enquire into the affair and has refused to listen to certain medical evidence obtained by Callicopoulo, who will be tried here before M. Scotidie. We are informed by the Greek Consulate that the name of the victim is Dandris. She died after three days of agony. A warrant has been issued for the arrest of Callicopoulo, who will be tried at the Criminal Assinas at Alexandria in December. M. Vernitki Hellenic, Vice Colonel, is investigating the case. The sum alleged to have been stolen is 300 pounds, and it is said that the loss of it turned the brain of Callicopoulos, who is well known among the Hellenic colony of Cairo.

div.head: DENISHWAI. M. P.'S SENTIMENTALISM. QUESTIONS IN THE HOUSE. OPINION IN ENGLAND. (Gazette's Special Service)

div.p: Those who are best able to judge Egypt's needs as a result of many years' experience of the country strongly deprecate the remarks which have been made by certain irresponsible individuals in the House of Commons during the last few days in connection with the verdict in the Danishwi affair. The utterances are looked upon as mere Little Englandiam and as having the savour of a desire for self-notoriety.

It is sincerely hoped by all who have the real welfare of Egypt at heart that the public at home will not be led away by the excessive deal of persons who are simply desirous of making political capital out of this unfortunate incident.

As an instance of how little the customs of the country are understood here, the wailing of the women at the time of the execution has been made much of and has produced a great effect on the feelings of individuals who are unaware that it is the custom for this to occur in all cases of death, and had no other significance at Denishwai.

I learn that the action of the Egyptian authorities has met with the entire approval of both the Europeans and the educated natives as being absolutely necessary to check any undue lawlessness and brutality on the part of the lower class of natives, who are not yet sufficiently advanced in the path of civilisation to appreciate unjust leniency.
It is considered to be most unlikely that the home Government will interfere in the matter.

In the House of Commons last Wednesday, Mr. Dillon asked the Prime Minister, in the absence of the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether he had been made aware of the fact that that morning four Egyptians were sentenced to death by the special court in connexion with the unfortunate affair at Denishwai, and whether he could undertake to obtain a respite of the sentence until the Foreign Minister had had an opportunity of personally examining the evidence given betro the tribunal.

The Prime Minister: I have not heard anything of the circumstance referred to by the hon. member, but I am sure we can trust to the discretion and humanity of my right hon. friend the Foreign Secretary (Sir Edward Grey) to see that everything is done that may be necessary. (Cheers.)

On the following day, Mr. Dillon asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether he had yet received any detailed information as to the aircumstarces which led to the affray: whether any of the natives were killed or injured; if any natives were killed or injured, would the British officers who took part in the affray be tried; whether the pigeons shot on these occasions were tame or wild pigeons ; whether occasions were tame or wild pigeons ; whether pigeon shooting in the neighbourhood of villages was a legal occupation in Egypt; whether in this instance the permission of the headman of the village had been obtained by the officers before they commenced to shoot ; what were the special grounds on which the Agent and Consul of Great Britain demanded that the accused Egyptians in this case should be sent for trial before the Special Tribunal; and whether there was any appeal from the Special Tribunal before which the Egyptians were to be tried.

Sir E. Grey.--I cannot answer all the details of the hon. member's question. I do not know whether any native was killed or injured, but our information is that the British officers, when they were attacked by the natives, gave up their guns and refused to fire in self-defence (hear, hear), and if any natives were killed, it was clearly not by the action of the British officers. When the report appeared in the Press yesterday, I telegraphed to know what the sentences were, and what were the facts established at the trial, saying that it was desirable we should know them before any death sentences were executed. The information I have received is as follows -The sentences were as stated in the Press, except that, I think, only two men were sentenced to penal servitude for life, whereas the Press stated four. With regard to the trial, the prisoners were defended by three of the best-known native advocates, who had a full hearing. The Court was unanimous as regards the prisoners found guilty, and the evidence clearly established premeditation and concerted actions. Thirty one of the prisoners were acquitted and 21 were found guilty. The Court expressed its opinion that the British officers had behaved with extreme forbearance and self-restraint. (Hcar, hear.) The chief attack took place after they had given up their guns and was persisted in with great brutality. I am also informed that, in the opinion of Judge Bond and Mr. Hayter, the Acting Judicial Adviser, both members of the Court, the first six prisoners would undoubtedly have been found guilty of murder by a British jury. The Special Court was composed of the Egyptian Minister for Foreign Affairs, who has had several years' experience in the Ministry of Justice in the absence of the latter ; Mr. Bond, Vice-President of the Native Court of Appeal, whose position is practically that of Dord Chief Justice ; Fethy Bey, President of the Cairo Native Court; Mr. Hayter, Action Judicial Adviser, formerly a Judge in the Sudan, and Colonel Ludlew, Officiating Judge Advocate.

There is no legal power of interference on the part either of the Egyptian Government or of the British Agency with the execution of the decision of the Court, and I am confident that the character of the tribunal is the greatest safeguard possible against a miscarriage of justice. (Cheers).

Mr. Dillon said the right hon. gentleman had not said whether it was legal or illegal to shoot there pignora in native villages, whether they were the property of the villagers, and whether a native woman wounded or killed before the officers were attacked.

Sir E. Grey-I understand that no one was wounded or killed before the officers were attacked, but that, after the guns had been given up by the officers, one of the guns was let off and caused injury to, I think, four people including one woman. But that was not by the officers. (Hear, hear) With regard to pigeon shooting. I understand that pigeons are never to be shot exempt with the consent of the headman of the village. In this case the officers arrived in the carriage of the local magnate and assumed that a completo understanding had taken place. As to the future, it is quite clear that, after each a serious incident as this, there should be no more pigeon shooting (hear, hear), and I understand that instructions were given some time so that it should cease.

Mr. Paul asked the right hon. gentleman whether he would consider the possibility of procuring through Lord Cromer the reminion of the floggings that formed part of the sentences in this case (Cries of "Why !")

Mr. Bylos asked the right hon. gentleman whether he had any information as to whether the persone sentenced to death had been executed, and, if not, whether, in all the circumstances of the case, it was imponible yet to save their lives (cries of "Oh"), inarmach as the nature of the fracas did not indicate murder in the sense in which we in England understood it. (Renewed cries of "Oh.")

Sir E. Grey-I have not actually heard whether the death sentences have been carried out, but they were to be executed at 2 o'clock this afternoon according to Egyptian time. I assume, therefore, that that has already taken place. With regard to the character of the crime, two of the Judges were men with English knowledge as well as experience in Egyptian law, and they stated that, in their opinion, not only four but six of the natives would have been convicted of murder by a British jury. I understand that the sentence of flogging were to be executed immediately: but, with regard to the general question, I quite sympathise with my hon.friend's feeling. which is shared by a large number of people,to the desirability of watching sentences of the kind very closely. I do not know the extent to which flogging is possible under Egyptian law, but I propose to take the opportunity of discussing that when Lord Cromar is in England, with a view to knowing to what extent it is possible and whether any change is desirable.

div.head: LIBERAL FEELING IN PARLIAMENT
div.p: In a note on Sir E. Grey's statement the Lobby correspondent of the "Tribune" says: The fuller details given by Sir Edward Grey have distinctly modified, if they have not entirely removed, the feeling of uneasiness felt by some Liberals as to the possibility of a miscarriage of justice. The Foreign Secretary assurance and Lord Cromer's statement that the tribunal was thoroughly competent, and that the natives were adequately represented, have given much satisfaction. At the same time, a feeling still exists among a certain number of Liberals that premeditation does not appear to be clearly proved, and that the prerogative of mercy might have been exercised. It may be said, however, that such objections are not raised by many members besides those who interviewed the Foreign Secretary on Wednesday,and that the anxiety caused by the perusal of a very brief report has, on the whole, been allayed.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H. H. the Khedive spends this week in Paris, and will leave for Divonne between the 10th and 15th inst. A report of the Danishwai ontrage and its consequences has been dispatched to his Highness by the Government.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS
div.p: The Council of Ministers, which met at Alexandria on Tuesday, approved the following :
The establishment of an abbatoir at Queens, Menonfieb Moudirieb.
The enlarging of Tantah station from the west side of the Defra Canal.
The constitution of the "Société Anonyme Egyptienne des Presses Allemandes."
The constitution of the "Electric Light and Power Supply Co."
The constitution of the "Egyptian Swiss Iron Works."

div.head: NEWS FROM ARABIA
div.p: According to "Al Zahir," Emir Mat'ib, nephew of the late Emir ibn Rashid, has sent back the prisoners taken in recent rezzies to Ibu el Saud, who has thanked his rival for his mazuan'mons act. It is stated by the same journal that the two opponents have now made peace and sworn eternal friendship.
The news seems a little too good to be true, if the recent history of Central Arabia be studied.

div.head: NEDWET EL ASSAL
HOW TO STAMP OUT COTTON PEST.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has made the following communication to the Press

Owing to favourable climatic conditions, and succulent foliage produced on early sown cotton by injudicious watering, a somewhat formidable attack of "Nadwat al Assal '' has appeared early this season; particularly on cotton cultivated on light sandy soils.
It should be clearly understood that the green Aphia found at present on the leaves of cotton, and its liquid product known as "Nadwat al Assal," which will appear later, are one and the same.
At the present stage, this post, by careful attention to the following instructions, may be easily and economically stamped out.

The small areas of cotton infected by this pest are usually more or low in the form of a circle on the outer fringe of the cotton field; but a few infected plants are occasionally found inside cotton areas near the main water channels, or in close proximity to water melons cucumbers, and other plants of the melon family growing in the cotton.

At the present stage of the attack a certain number of leaves only are infected. If all infected foliage is at once picked and destroyed (a work which can be easily and economically carried out everywhere) no danger, or loss of crop is likely to occur.

The cotton plants with clean stems and terminal buds, if now freed from the Aphis, will, by this additional assistance to ripening their wood quickly break into strong healthy foliage and flowers, capable of carrying a full crop of lint.
All leaves on infected plants should be at once picked and burned, commencing on the outside of the infected area and working inwards until the clean stems and terminal buds only remain.

All infected leaves should be carefully hand picked by children with a little shaking as possible and the aphie covered foliage collected in tin vessels of any kind, such as petroleum tins, pails, tin mugs or any other available vessels, in which they should be carried to the fire and burned, each vessel being afterwards washed or scoured with sand or earth to clean it from any aphis crawling on the sides, and, on the completion of the work, the earth round the bare stem (from which the leaves have been picked) should be dug up and broken fine, to destroy aphis that have fallen during the picking.

On no account should persons employed in destroying "Nedwet El Amal" be allowed to enter clean cotton-for the danger of infection by aphis carried on clothing is a point requiring serious attention. The present practice of placing infected leaves in gallabia or in baskets is strongly condemned, owing to the extreme danger of extending infection to clean cotton plants.

All infected areas must on the completion of the work be carefully inspected by a responsible person, why must be sure that no infected leaves remain, and, as an extra precaution against carrying infection, gallabias should be beaten in order to rid them of any aphis clinging to them.
When the sticky fluid known as Nedwet El Assal appears on all parts of the plants, the success of hand picking infected foliage is considerably diminished.
If these simple instructions are carefully adhered to, there is every hope that the pest may be successfully stamped out, and a serious loss to the coming season's cotton crop averted.
Whenever "sprayers' ' are forthcoming these should be used freely, as prescribed by circular of last year.

div.head: COTTON LANDS OF EGYPT. A NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANY.
div.p: This concern was registered in London on June 25th with a capital of £440,386. 5s. in 110,000 shares of £4 each and 7,725 of 1s. each. The object of the company is to acquire the benefit of a contract between the Société Anonyme du Behera and Fratelli Salinas and Co., for the sale by the said société of about 14,000 feddans of land, and to carry on the business indicated by the title.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Niger arrived at Marseilles yesterday morning from Alexandria.
The Moss liner Menes sailed yesterday afternoon for Liverpool, via Malta and Algiers, with passengers, mails, and general cargo.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LAND AND GENERAL TRUST.
div.p: A circular has been issued to shareholders in the above company informing them that a contract, subject to the approval of the shareholders, has been signed for the fusion of Egyptian Land and General Trust, Limited, with the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company Limited, on the basis already mentioned by as Provision has been made in the contract for the cases where bearer warrants have been issued, and for an agreed amount being paid if the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Limited, declare a dividend for their financial year ending 31st March, 1906. A general meeting of shareholders is being summoned to take their views on the matter, and if they approve, then to confirm the agreement, and pass the necessary special resolutions for giving effect to the proposed fusion, and for the voluntary liquidation of the company. A very general desire (the circular states) has been expressed by a large body of shareholders to carry out the proposed amalgamation, and the Board believe that it is expedient for the shareholders, in all the circumstances, to conclude the arrangements, which will be explained in full detail at the general meeting.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE
div.p: Under the distinguished patronage and presence of His Excellency the governor of Alexandria and Mr. B. B. Gould, I.S.O, His Britannic Majesty's Consul-General, who was accompanied by Mr. Gould, a gala performance of The Geisha, in aid of the Maltese Benevolent Society, was given last evening by the talented company of artistes now occupying the boards of the above theatre, and although this evergreen favourite has been produced on several previous occasions the popularity of the opera was evinced by the crowded audience that greeted the rise of the curtain, and who were enthusiastic in their appreciation of the efforts of the performers.

The first set of the opera lacked vitality at the commencement, and this was doubtless due to the very depressing tempo at which some of the numbers were taken. This was particularly noticeable in the case of the "amorous gold fish," who evidently had a pretty trying time of it. With this exception the performance was an excellent one and went with a swing to the drop of the curtain.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
div.p: Egyptian cotton has been quite neglected this week, and scarcely sufficient business done to test prices. Quotations are nominal at the following redactions, viz: -1/4 per lb for Fully Good Fair Brown and below, and all upper; ⅛ per lb for Good to Fine Brown. In Futures a moderate business has been done, and the following are

American Futures.--The market this week has again been under the same influences as last week, namely a renewed liquidation of the July position coupled with great deal of manipulation, and of straddle operations, (buying in New York, and selling in this market). Prices have fluctuated daily ; the net result, however, shows practically very little change from those of last Thursday. There is no particular feature beyond the absolute absence of any speculative interest from any side, and the general impression that the crop as a whole has made good progress during the present month has no doubt largely tended to induce the liquidation of the "Bull" interests. Attention will now be directed to the next Bureau report which it is generally anticipated will be favourable.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY. KHEDIVAL YACHT CLUB.
div.p: REGATTA
The following is the results of yesterday's regatta:
The wind was strong from the N.W., which was responsible for several accidents during the afternoon.

The Iris gave up soon after the start and went to her moorings. The Calypso carried away her roller jib, and the Cattelays tore her mainsail on the bowsprit of schooner at anchor. "The Nanine and San Pareille both fouled the mark-buoy when finishing and are therefore disqualified The Delikanli started nearly 3 minutes late and the Moss over 14 minutes late. She however managed to secure a place owing to the Calypso breaking down.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The marriage of Mr. Samuel Gurney Shoppard, D.S.O., Chairman of the Abosnkir Company, and Miss Eileen Mary Winchester Clowes was solemaried last week in the parish church of Hayes, Kent. Miss Clowes is the daughter of the late Mr. Winchester Clowes, of Rosenberg, Hitehan, and Mr. Sheppard is the son of the late Mr. Samuel Gurney Sheppard, of Leggatte, Potters Bar, and is a major in the Herta Imperial Yeomanry. The clergy officiating were the Rev. George Clowes, rector of Hayes, uncle of the bride, and the Rev. G. F. Richardson, vicar of St. Jame's, Doncaster, brother-in-law of the bride groom. The bride was given away by her brother, Captain St. George Clowes, and the bridesmaids were the Mines Mwyndag Clowes (sister of the bride) Robin Clowes, Mary Kaight Clowes, and Ella Copleston Clowes (cousins). and Miss Penelope Dalme Radcliffe, and the two little Miss Joan Sheppard and Ruth Richardson (niece of the bride groom). Masters D'Oylay Sheppard (nephew of the bridegroom) and Graham Buckley acted as pages. Mr. Geoffrey Lubbock was the best man. A guard of honour was furnished by Mr. Sheppard's regiment. Later in the day Mr. and Mrs. Sheppard left for Marsh Court, Stockbridge, lest by Mr. Herbert Johnson.
H.M.I. the Shah of Persia has conferred the Order of Shir-Khorshid of the lst Class on Ibrahim Pacha Abdon, a notable of Benhs.

div.head: Egyptian Land and General Trust, LIMITED.

div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the above named Company will be held at Winchester House, in the City of London, on Thursday, the 19th of July, 1906, at two o'clock in the afternoon for the purpose of considering, and if thought fit, passing the subjoined Resolutions. Should the subjoined Resolutions, Nod. 2 and 3, be passed at the said Meeting or any adjournment thereof by the requisite majority, the same will be submitted for confirmation as Special Resolutions at a Second Extraordinary General Meeting which will be subsequently convened.

div.head: RESOLUTIONS.
div.p: 1. "That the proposed amalgamation with the 'Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Limited,' is hereby approved, and that the provisional Agreement, dated the 22nd June, 1906, and made between the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Limited, and this Company for that purpose be and the same is hereby approved and confirmed, and that the Directors be and are hereby authorised to carry the same into effect with or without such modifications or additions as they may think fit and to enter into and execute any further agreements which may be necessary for that purpose."

2. "That the Articles of Association of the Company be altered by adding the following Clause at the end thereof, viz. That, notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein before contained, in the event of the liquidation of the Company consequent upon the approval of a scheme of amalgamation with the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Limited, there shall be returned to each Member the amount paid upon on each Share held by him in excess of 10/- per Share, together with interest thereon at the rate of 6 per cent. per annum from the respective dates of payment of such excess until the date of repayment. Each Member entitled to one or more complete lots of Six Shares in this Company upon which at least 10/- per Share has been paid, and all be entitled to receive one fully paid Share in the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Limited, in respect of each complete lot of Six Shares held by him in this Company upon which at least 10/- per Share has been paid, and each Member holding a fraction of Six Shares shall receive the same fractional proportion of the net proceeds of sale of one fully paid Share in the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Limited, which shall be sold by the Liquidators, in such manner, at such time, at such price or prices, and generally on such terms and conditions as they may think fit. In the event of the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Limited, paying to this Company a further sum equal to one shilling per Share in this Company, having at least 10/- paid up, such sum eshall be distributed amongst the Members of this Company, ratably in proportion to the number of Shares held by them respectively in this Company.'"

3. "That the Company be wound up voluntarily, and that W. T. Johns, of Palmerston House, Old Broad Street, London, E.C., and P.J. Horte, of Gesham House, Old Broad Street, London, B.C., be and are hereby appointed Liquidators for the purpose of such winding up at a fee of £315 and expenses." Dated the 29th day of June, 1906.
By order of the Board, MACK and PALMER, Secretaries.

N.E. --All holders of Share Warrants to Bearer desiring to attend and vote either personally or by proxy at the above Meeting must deposit their Share Warrants with the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Limited, in London, Cairo, or Alexandria, at least three days before the time fixed for holding the Meeting.

div.head: Egyptian Trust and Investment Limited. NOTICE.
div.p: The Directors of the Egyptian Trust and Investment Ltd. beg to notify to the shareholders that it has been decided to make a further call of 10/-per share, thus making the shares fully paid.

The second call of 5/-per share will be received at the Anglo Egyptian Bank Ltd. Alexandria on the 21st. July 1906 after which date an interest of 7 % will be charged. The third call of 5 per share will be received at the Anglo Ezyptian Bank Ltd. Alexandria on the 21st. August 1903 after which date an interest of 7% will be charged.
Shareholders are particularly requested to note that payments will only be received at the Bank on presentation of the call letter and the nominative Certificate.

div.head: RUSSIAN CRISIS. MUTINY AMONG TROOPS. STATE OF SEIGE IN ODESSA.

div.p: Three rifle battalions at Askabad have mutinied, demanding the removal of the officers and non-commissioned officers and the appointment of officers from the rankings. The Government's land proposals are scouted by all parties. (Reuter)
All police were withdrawn from the streets yesterday, owing to constant murders of members of the force. (Reuter)

The trial of the members of the workmen's delegates committee, who organized the Moscow rising in December, has begun. The accused and witnesses hammed the "Marseillaise" during the proceedings. (Reuter)
It is stated that the Cossack, refused to fire on the strikers at Baka. A state of siege has been proclaimed in the Odessa district. (Havas)
356 of the native vanguard were killed in yesterday's fighting in Natal. (Reuter)

The inhabitants are scared by the native attacks on citizens in the suburbs. Many persons have been stabbed, beaten, and robbed. It is beloved that the outrages are the result of the agitation in Natal. (Reuter)

div.head: THE CONGO QUESTION. DEBATE IN HOUSE OF LORDS.

div.p: Cricket Hampshire beat West Indians by six wickets. Warwickshire beat Sussex by an innings and 25 runs. Northamptonshire beat Leicestershire by an innings and 40 runs. The rest of the matches were drawn. (Reuter)
House Of Commons.- Mr. Birrell moved the amendment to the Education Bill, omitting part II, namely, clauses 14 to 24 dealing with endowments. (Reuter)
The German Crown Princess has been safely delivered of a son. (Reuter)
The Crown Princesa has been safely delivered of a son. The Deputies voted congratulations to the Emperor and the Crown Prince. (Havas)

Cricket Hampshire beat West Indians by six wickets. Warwickshire beat Sussex by an innings and 25 runs. Northamptonshire beat Leicestershire by an innings and 40 runs. The rest of the matches were drawn. (Reuter)

div.head: THE DENISHWAI ASSAULT. THE PRESS AND THE SCENTANCES
div.p: The home press in the main expresses cordial approval of the finding of the special tribunal which considered the case of the natives involved in the outrage on British officers at Denishwai, and the punishment meted out to them, though certain of the Liberal journals consider the sentences rather too drastic, a view that is entirely out of harmony with the facts contained in the evidence placed before the court. We append a few excerpts:

div.head: "TIMES"
div.p: The Egyptian authorities have to deal not only with a brutal and unprovoked murder, but with a revolt upon a small scale on the part of the lowest and most fanatical of the Mussulman population. That is a thing which must be put down at all costs, and the more vigorously because our army of occupa is very small, and would speedily have its hands full all over the country if the nation got abroad that fanatical outrages can be perpetrated with impunity. The ring-leaders in this case have been amply identified not only by the British officers attacked, but by native witnesses. The severe sentences passed upon them are not only justified, but imperatively demanded, by the circumstances. So long as we remain responsible for the government of Egypt we have to make our authority respected, and must suppress outbreaks of fanaticism, however prompted, with unsparing rigour.

div.head: "TELEGRAPH"
div.p: The prisoners had an absolutely fair trial, were allowed counsel, and had on the bench native representatives of the Egyptian Government. The defence, though in able hands, was extremely lame, and rather directed to disclaim premeditation than to exonerate the murderer. There is a curious theory amongst philanthropic Radicals that it is harsh to punish many people for a single crime; "one murder," they say in effect, "one convict." If there are any mitigating circumstances in the case of which the British public is ignorant the decision may safely be left in the hands of the Egyptian Government. Lord Cromer is at present on his way home, but his policy of fairness and determination to protect the interests and rights of the fellaheen suffers no diminution in his absence.

div.head: "MORNING POST"
div.p: The outrage and the severity of the sentences are unique in the history of the British Occupation. It was shown in court to the satisfaction, we are glad to say, of native as well as English judges that the unoffending victims were deliberately enticed to the scene of the outrage and that the murderous fanatical attack was carefully premeditated Apparently had it not been for Captain Bostock's successful warning of the Mounted Infantry patrol several miles distant, and the friendly attitude of some of the village headmen, all the British officers might have met with Captain Ball's fate. There is, therefore, not the slightest reason for considering the sentences inflicted by the Special Tribunal as erring on the side of severity, and there is no doubt that the mass of European opinion in Egypt and that of the native population which appreciates the integrity of our administration will endorse the verdict.

div.head: "STANDARD"
div.p: Justice has been done on the murderers of Captain Bull, and on the assailants of the other British officers who were his companions. No one will feel a pang except those extraordinary persons, some of whom are unfortunately members of the House of Commons, to whom the life of a British officer is apparently a fit plaything for any barbarian in the world. The men were tried before a civil tribunal, constituted not ad hoc, but in accordance with an existing agreement between the Khedivial Government and the representatives of the British Protectorate; the accused had the benefit of the best advocacy available at the Egyptian Bar, and the court, European and native alike, unanimously found them guilty of a perfectly unprovoked and deliberately planned attack. Not only as reparation for the death of Captain Bull, and the injuries inflicted on Major Pine-Coffin, but also for the tranquillity of Egypt, it was necessary that a condign example should be made of the brutal villagers of Denishwai. Their fellows will now perceive that the arm of the Egyptian Government, backed by that of Great Britain, is not to be stayed by intrigue which has for its object the overthrow of the régime under which Egypt has, prospered, even in the supposed interests of the Padishah. Quicquid delirant reges, plectuntur Achivi. Moslem fanaticism appears to have taken fire from recent events to the undoing of these minor criminals, while those who have lit the flame are out of the reach of punishment; but this is what only too often happens in this imperfect world. We may hope, however, that the conspirators whose example aroused the sheep-like fellahin of Danishwai to violence will recognise in time their own impotence.

div.head: "PALL MALL GAZETTE"
div.p: The exemplary sentences passed on the murderers of Captain Bull and on thei accomplices were abundantly justified by the nature and circumstances of the crime. It is perfectly clear, first, that the attack upon the British officers was in no way provoked by the victims, and secondly, that it was due to the recrudescence of fanaticism which has been noticed among the fellaheen during the past year. ln these circumstances, even if there had been any ground for the extension of mercy to the authors of the outrage, such indulgence would have been an act of criminal weakness. In view of the almost microscopic dimensions of the British garrison in Egypt, the moral prestige of the "Red Locust" (as discontented natives call the British soldier) must not be allowed to suffer the slightest diminution.

div.head: "GLOBE"
div.p: On the clearest evidence, it is now established beyond controversy that the attack on the British officers was not in the least spontaneous, but had been planned and carefully arranged in every detail beforehand. Murder was meant, and murder was brutally accomplished in one instance, by a band of ruffians armed for that very purpose... But it is on Abdel Magid Bey, the notable who invited the little party to shoot pigeons at Depishwai, and on the local Omdeh, who absented himself precisely at the time of their arrival, that suspicion of complicity chiefly rests. Both of these functionaries must have been well aware of the evil reputation of the Denishwai people for lawlessness and anti-British sentiment. It should be made the matter for most searching inquiry, consequently, how it occurred to the one to Dame Denishwai as the best place in the locality, for pigeon-shooting, and to the other to try to clear himself from responsibility for what he knew was about to happen by removing himself to an adjacent village until the affair had been brought off. It should be especially ascertained whether these officials ever had close relations, political or other, with the nests of Turkish intriguers at Cairo and Alexandria.

div.head: "WESTMINISTER GAZETTE"
div.p: We dead hardly say that we regard the sentences on the Egyptian natives as at best a very regrettable necessity...So far as we can see, those natives were given a perfectly fair trial, and the sentences are to punish individual guilt and not collective responsibility. That being so, there seems to be no case for interference with the sentences. It has to be remembered that the officers were in uniform, and there seems little doubt that the attack was due, in part at all events, to fanaticism. We have no option but to make it clear that such outbursts cannot be tolerated.

div.head: "TRIBUNE"
div.p: We know nothing of the competence or incompetence of the tribunal by which these sentences were giver, and it may have been impossible to avoid passing them. But we must own that we could wish that they had less of the appearance of vindictiveness. There is something repugnant in the administration of punishment in each wholesale measure even if it be unavoidable, and in the present case, when we compare the official report with the cabled summaries of evidence", we think some extenuating circumstances appear which might have mitigated the penalty on all but the actual murderers.

A. V. Thomson, Secretary for Egypt.
The Money Market.

The position of the money market today reflects its general condition throughout the past six months. Doubt and uncertainty have been the prevailing features, but even the most pessimistic prophet did not, at the beginning of the year, forecast the state of stringency under which we have been labouring.

The general state of trade throughout the country has undoubtedly been good, but it must nevertheless have been hampered by the dearness of money, which, of course, affects general credit, making it relatively dear. It is impossible to survey the general field of finance without feeling that some disturbing factors are at work, the removal of which is a necessity before we shall be able to enjoy the ease which comes from normal times. No doubt the unfortunate state of poor distracted Russia is a serious disturbing element, affecting us, not to a great extent directly, but to a considerable degree through the Continental centres. The United States, with its booming trade on the one hand, and sad earthquake disaster on the other, has doubtless had a much more direct effect.

The trouble created by these disturbing factors has, of course, only been intensified by the inadequacy of our gold reserves, and the only satisfaction to be gleaned is from the fact that the question is likely to receive some earnest attention. To-day we see the matter exemplified. The Bank has gained considerable strength during the last few weeks, and there is a good supply of floating credits. Notwithstanding this, owing to the fact that there is some doubt as to what will become of the gold supplies, amounting to about one million, during next week, a feeling of uncertainty has arisen, and in some quarters the more hopeful view which had been gaining ground bag been abandoned. France, of course, is bidding for the gold, and the exchange at 25.15 is low enough to warrant her taking it ; then the weakness of the American rate may result, at any moment, in gold being taken for New York, notwithstanding that the price of the metal bus advanced to about 77s. 10d. It is, therefore, time that some means should be adopted to avoid the disturbance caused by even the withdrawal of these comparatively small events. Credit dealers are now calling the day to day money rate about 3% and are charging 3 1/2% for weekly advances, and the discount rate for 3 months bills stands firm at 3 1/4%. Six months bills, which now take us into next year, and will have to be carried for a considerable period on dear money, are quoted at 3 5/16 to 33%

The Bank Return is not very interesting this week. The principal feature is the addition of nearly two millions to the "Other Deposits," which, however, has been added at the expense of Other Securities, showing the market's borrowings from the Bank, in order to make a good showing in the half-yearly balance sheets.
The Stock Markets.

So far from the reduction of the Bank rate tending to an improvement in speculative business on the Stock Exchange, as we have from time to time been told would be the case, the conditions this week have been the most depressing experienced for a considerable time past, and the disappointment of dealers has been intensified by the fact that on Wednesday the markets sharply recovered from the state of extreme weakness prevailing on the first two days of the week, only to relapse again into idleness yesterday. A significant instance of the despondency is found in the remarkable decline in Consols, which up to Tuesday had lost ⅞ since the Bank rate was reduced. Enormous quantities of these stocks have been disposed of, chiefly, it is stated, by the insurance companies, who have thas been releasing funds to meet their recent losses. When the selling ceased the quotation considerably improved, but yesterday it was down again.
Fortunately, the settlement has passed off without any failures being reported, though it is understood that the events of the past account have caused very grave anxiety in more than one case.

The gravity of Russian affairs has continued to make itself felt on the Continental bourses, and though there has not been much liquidation of the bonds, support has been studiously withheld. The Stook Exchange has closely followed this example, and the quotations remain at the low level touched last week.
About the only satisfactory feature in the markets has been the improvement in home rails, which is none the less welcome because it is long overdue.
Consols.

The gilt-edged share market has been in a parlous state, and at one time the quotation for Console was within 1/18 of the lowest point touched during the war. The conclusion of the liquidations responsible for this was signalized by a rise in the price to 88 ¼ , but yesterday there was a further drop to 87 15/16, at which they close to-night. The new Irish Land Loan, after relapsing to par, is now ⅜ premium.
Foreign Bonds.

The reports of stormy meetings of the Duma and the unsettled state of the country districts in Russia have not been lost upon the bourses of Berlin and Paris, and although the "panicky" feeling which dominated the markets last week has been absent, Russian securities have been left severely alone. On the Stock Exchange, the Fours dropped 3/4 to 78, and the new loan to 3 1/2 discount, but subsequently benefited by the general cheerfulness on Wednesday. They leave off to-night at 78 1/2 and 3 ⅛ discount respectively. Japanese stocks are steady. The 4 1/2 % (1905) are higher, and the Fours have put on ⅛.

Home Ralls. Last week we ventured the opinion that the improvement noticed in the home railway market might be the commencement of the revival which has been prophesied for some months past. The strength of this section since our last encourages us in the hope. In spite of the depression in other markets home rails have kept firm, and in several of the heavies substantial advances have been marked, London and North Western putting on 1 ¼ in one day. The reaction yesterday bad only a slight effect, and in the main the higher prices are being maintained. Speculation is rife regarding the forthcoming reports and dividends of the railway companies which are being awaited with great interest, and with confidence. The past half year has been a remarkably successful period for British lines, and the aggregate increase in profits has been enormous. The traffic gains of the North Eastern and L. and N. W. alone for the twenty-five weeks to date amount to close upon half-a-million pounds, while the Midland and Lancashire are respectively £153,000 and £101,000 to the good.

Americans. The American market started the week steady, but yesterday, following the break up in Wall Street the previous night, there was a substantial amount of liquidation, and prices were severely affected, several of the shares losing from 2 to 2 3/4 points. To-day there has been a return to better conditions, and appreciable advances are recorded. The demand for Baltimore and Ohio seems to have been satisfied, and the closing quotation is about last week's level. Chicago Milwaukee have been a bad point, and up to last night had lost as much as 7 since our last. They have, however, participated in to-day's improvement, and leave off 3 better on the day at 179 ½ . Steel Common and Preference have been weak, but close firmer at 37 1/2 and 105.

Egyptians. Although there is still an entire absence of business in the Egyptian market, prices are steady at about last week's levels. National Banks, after being up to 25 ¾ , close 25 ½ Agricultarals close easier at 9 ⅝, after being 9 3/4. Daira Sanieh Ordinary are a very dull market, with a good many small sellers about, the price being 17. The Deferred are 99-100. Delta Preference Bearer remain firm at 11 7/8, and Delta Land and Investment are steady round about 3 5/8. Daira Sagar are a shade better at 5 1/16 Union Foncière are unmentioned at 6 3/16 and Bank of Abyssinia at ⅜ discount. New Egyptian, in which there was a fair business last week, have not kept up to the best price of 1 ½ buyers, the last price being 1 7/16. Egyptian Estates are a better market at 1 3/4. the Defferred at a little better than 10. Egyptian Markets are a nominal market at 1 5/16, and Salt and Soda have been offered down to 23s. without response. There has been some demand for Khadivial Mail ordinary at 1 5/8, and the Preference have changed hands at 4 3/8. Bank of Romania are down again to 10 1/4. The smaller-priced Egyptian shares are unmentioned.

Mining. There hs been a farther downward tendency in the South African market, and Kaffirs have been almost as low as at any time during the session. The Chinese labour question is still acting as a bogey, speculators being nervous respecting the Government's real intentions in the matter. Rand Mines weakened to 5 ⅞ and East Rands are 3 15/16 as compared with 6 5/32 and 3 31/32 a week ago. The Egyptian mining section is quiet, and there appear to be no buyers about, but this is not surprising considering that the Egyptian holidays are in full swing. Nile Valleys close at 6s., after being 5s. 6d., and United Africans are 1/8 lower at 7/8. Um Rus are unohanged at 9d. Trust and Investment have lost 1/16 at ⅜ - ½.
